title: PM Meets Japanese Lawmaker to Solve Bilateral Dispute
text:
Prime Minister Lee Nak-yon on Monday told a senior Japanese lawmaker that Korea could reconsider scrapping a bilateral intelligence-sharing pact if Japan lifts export curbs.

Lee made the proposal during a closed-door lunch with Takeo Kawamura, the head of the Japan-South Korea Parliamentarians' Union. "Korea could reconsider the termination of the General Security of Military Information Agreement if Japan returns to normal from the steps it has taken," the Prime Minister's Office quoted Lee as saying.

Kawamura, who came to Seoul on a four-day visit that ended Tuesday, told reporters, "I told Prime Minister Lee that [the bilateral spat] stemmed from compensation for forced labor victims, and that must be resolved separately."

Kawamura later briefed Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe about the results of his visit. Abe said the resolution of problems involving compensation of Korean forced labor victims "is top priority" and added that Korea needs to uphold its agreements with Japan, according to NHK.

Earlier, Lee said in meetings with government and ruling party officials that Seoul is willing to reconsider scrapping the intelligence pact if Japan puts Korea back on its "whitelist" of preferential trading partners.

Meanwhile, the Foreign Ministry said the Korean Embassy in Tokyo received a parcel last Tuesday containing what appeared to be a bullet with a threatening message. "I've got a rifle and I'm hunting Koreans," the massage said. It was addressed to the former Korean ambassador to Japan, Lee Su-hoon. The sender has not been identified.

The Asahi Shimbun newspaper reported that the message made no mention of compensation for forced labor victims, making it "unclear" if it was related to the current bilateral spat.
description: PM Meets Japanese Lawmaker to Solve Bilateral Dispute
